Hi,
         This version looks fairly expensive and I'm not sure exactly what 
kind of curve it's going to give you.

         The version I was suggesting is basically an implementation of 
first-order decay, e.g. where:

         dx/dt = c(x0 - x)

         c is the rate constant, x is the current "level" of whatever is 
decaying and X0 is the level towards which it is decaying.  (In a lot of 
cases X0 is zero.)  This is a very natural form of decay (e.g. many 
chemical reactions have these kinetics as does radioactive decay and the 
simpler kinds of thermal equilibration) and also dead cheap to 
calculate.  Its downside is that it is only asymptotic to x0 and 
technically never quite reaches it, but that's quite common with natural 
phenomena.

         The other thing is that keeping an array of values from previous 
timesteps feels a bit unnatural to me also.  It's a bit like a "bucket 
brigade" delay line (an electronic circuit) and if I was building one of 
those I'd expect to use a row of neurones.

         Anyway, I would use first-order decay if I were doing it.

         Ian B

At 17:01 30/10/2004, you wrote:
>I pasted the code I was playing with for 'leaky' integration. It's a 
>computational method to solve fractional integration or derivation of 
>functions. It came out of a paper for nonexponential decay of piezoelectrics:
>http://content.aip.org/APCPCS/v582/i1/175_1.html
>
>I modified this code when I dropped into my version of Windows neat to 
>make a linked list out of f, and pop the front when the list got bigger 
>than I wanted, and then made the q a genetic parameter.
>The whole experiment never got anywhere, because school started, and I had 
>to start going to class and 'learning' stuff.
>Hope this is usefull.
>chad
>
>
>/*---------------------------------------------------------------------------
>Fractional derivatie is a function to compute an arbitrary derivative or
>integral. A positive value for q performs a derivative, while a negative
>value performs an integration.
>f[] set of historical measurements, oldest first.
>N is the number of values in the data set.
>q is the differintegration value.
>---------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
>double fractionalDerivative(float f[], int N, float q)
>{
>float Numerator = N-q-1;
>float Denominator = N;
>double PartialSum = f[0];
>for (int index=1;index {
>PartialSum = f[index+1]+ PartialSum*(Numerator-index)/(Denominator-index);
>}
>return PartialSum;
>}
